pages.text:
{{multiple image
 |align=right |direction=vertical
 |image1=Kaaba at night.jpg |caption1=The current Qiblah of Islam, the [[Kaaba]] in the [[Great Mosque of Mecca|Great Mosque]] of [[Mecca]] |width1=220
 |image2=Jerusalem-2013(2)-Aerial-Temple Mount-(south exposure).jpg |caption2=The former Qiblah of Islam, the [[al-Aqsa Mosque]] ([[Temple Mount]]),<ref name="Hartsock2014"/> in the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]] of [[Jerusalem]] |width2=220
}}

The '''Qibla'''  ({{lang-ar|{{script|Arab|قِبْلَة|}}}}, "Direction", also transliterated as '''Qiblah''', '''Qibleh''', '''Kiblah''', '''Kıble''' or '''Kibla'''), is the direction that should be faced when a [[Muslim]] [[prayer|prays]] during ''[[Salah|ṣalāh]]'' ({{lang-ar|صَلَاة}}). It is fixed as the direction of the [[Kaaba]] in the [[Hejaz]]i<ref name="MWGD2001">{{cite book |last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Merriam-Webster's Geographical Dictionary |page=479 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Co_VIPIJerIC&pg=PA479 |year=2001 |isbn=0 87779 546 0 |access-date=2013-03-17}}</ref> city of [[Mecca]]. Most [[mosque]]s contain a wall [[Niche (architecture)|niche]] that indicates the Qibla, which is known as a ''[[mihrab|miḥrâb]]'' ({{lang-ar|مِحْرَاب}}). Most [[Multifaith space|multifaith prayer rooms]] will also contain a Qibla, although usually less standardized in appearance than one would find within a mosque.<ref>{{cite news |title=Multifaith Spaces: Objects |work=[[University of Manchester]] |url=http://www.multi-faith-spaces.org |first=Chris |last=Hewson |date=March 1, 2012 |accessdate=September 14, 2012}}</ref>

Muslims all praying towards the same point is traditionally considered to symbolize the unity of the ''[[Ummah]]'' ({{lang-ar|اُمَّة}}, the community Muslims worldwide), under the ''[[Sharia|Sharīʿah]]'' ({{lang-ar|شَرِيْعَة}}, Law of God). The Qibla also has importance beyond ''ṣalāh'', and plays a part in various ceremonies. The head of an animal that is slaughtered using ''[[Halal|ḥalāl]]'' ({{lang-ar|حَلَال}}, 'Allowed') methods is usually aligned with the Qibla. After death, Muslims are usually buried with the body at right angles to the Qibla and the face turned right towards the direction of the Qibla.{{Citation needed|date=February 2019}}

== History ==
{{See also|Abraham in Islam#Relationship with Islamic shrines}}
{{Fiqh|theological}}
[[File:Masjid Qiblatain.jpg|left|thumb|[[Masjid al-Qiblatayn]] in [[Medina]] is the place where the Qiblah was switched towards Mecca]]

According to the traditional Muslim view, the Qiblah in the [[Prophets of Islam|Islamic prophet]] [[Muhammad in Islam|Muhammad]]'s time was originally the [[Temple Mount|Noble Sanctuary]] in the city of [[Jerusalem]], similar to [[Judaism]].<ref name="Hartsock2014">{{cite journal |last1=Hartsock |first1=Ralph |date=2014-08-27 |title=The temple of Jerusalem: past, present, and future |journal=Jewish Culture and History  |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=199-201 |doi=10.1080/1462169X.2014.953832 }}</ref><ref name="Abu Sway">{{citation |author=Mustafa Abu Sway |title=The Holy Land, Jerusalem and Al-Aqsa Mosque in the Qur’an, Sunnah and other Islamic Literary Source |url=http://www.wcfia.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/Abusway_0.pdf |publisher=[[Central Conference of American Rabbis]] |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728001911/http://www.wcfia.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/Abusway_0.pdf |archive-date=2011-07-28 |df= }}</ref> This Qiblah was used for over 13 years, from 610 CE until 623 CE. Seventeen months after [[Muhammad]]'s [[Hijra (Islam)|622 CE arrival]] in [[Medina]] – the date is given as 11 February 624 – the Qiblah became oriented towards the Kaaba in Mecca.<ref>''In the Lands of the Prophet'', Time-Life, p. 29</ref><ref name="Watt1974">{{cite book |author=William Montgomery Watt |title=Muhammad: prophet and statesman |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zLN2hNidLw4C&pg=PA113 |accessdate=29 December 2011 |date=7 February 1974 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-881078-0 |pages=112–113}}</ref> According to traditional accounts from Muhammad's [[Sahabah|companions]], the change happened very suddenly during the noon prayer in Medina, in a mosque now known as ''[[Masjid al-Qiblatayn|Masjid al-Qiblaṫayn]]'' ({{lang-ar|مَسْجِد الْقِبْلَتَيْن}}, "Mosque of the Two Qiblahs").<ref name="Watt1974"/> Muhammad was leading the prayer when he received revelations from [[God in Islam|God]] instructing him to take the Kaaba as the Qiblah (literally, "Turn then Thy face in the direction of the Sacred Mosque.").<ref name="Watt1974"/><ref>Sura 2 ([[Al-Baqara]]), [[ayah]] 144, {{Cite quran|2|144|s=ns}}</ref> According to the traditional accounts contained in the [[hadith]] and [[Sirat Rasul Allah|sira]], Muhammad, who had been facing Jerusalem, upon receiving this revelation, immediately turned around to face Mecca, and those praying behind him also did so.<ref name="Watt1974"/>

Some have claimed that the [[Qur'an]] does not identify or allude to Jerusalem as being the first Qiblah, and that the practice of facing Jerusalem is only mentioned in [[Prophetic biography|traditional biographies of Muhammad]], or [[hadith]] collections.<ref name="MayerMourad2008">{{cite book |author1=Tamar Mayer |author2=Suleiman Ali Mourad |title=Jerusalem: idea and reality |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g74fAGZRFk0C&pg=PA87 |accessdate=5 October 2010 |year=2008 |publisher=Routledge |page=87}}</ref> There is also disagreement as to when the practice started and for how long it lasted.<ref name="MayerMourad2008"/> Some sources say the Jerusalem Qiblah was used for a period of between sixteen and eighteen months.<ref name="Friedmann2003">{{cite book|author=Yohanan Friedmann |title=Tolerance and coercion in Islam: interfaith relations in the Muslim tradition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a0nToibj6K4C&pg=PA31 |accessdate=5 October 2010|year=2003 |publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=|page=31}}</ref> The Jewish custom of facing Jerusalem for prayer may have influenced the Muslim Qiblah.<ref name="BritannicaHoiberg2000">{{cite book|author1=Britannica |author2=Dale Hoiberg |author3=Indu Ramchandani |title=Students' Britannica India|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ISFBJarYX7YC&pg=PA224 |accessdate=5 October 2010|year=2000 |publisher=Popular Prakashan |isbn=|page=224}}</ref> Others surmise that the use of Jerusalem as the direction of prayer was to either induce the Jews of Medina to convert to Islam or to "win over their hearts".<ref name="Friedmann2003"/> When relations with the [[Jews]] soured, Muhammad changed the Qiblah towards Mecca.<ref name="BritannicaHoiberg2000"/> Another reason given why the Qiblah was changed is that Jews viewed the use of Jerusalem as signalling the Muslims' intention of joining their religion. It was changed to discredit this assumption.<ref name="Friedmann2003"/> Others state that it was changed because Muhammad was angered by that city or its people, and not because of his conflict with the Jews.<ref name="Altafsir">{{cite web|title=Altafsir 2:144||url= https://www.altafsir.com/Tafasir.asp?tMadhNo=0&tTafsirNo=74&tSoraNo=2&tAyahNo=144&tDisplay=yes&UserProfile=0&LanguageId=2 }}</ref>

In Medieval times, Muslims travelling abroad used an [[astrolabe]] to find the Qiblah.<ref name="winterburn">{{cite web|last1=Winterburn |first1=Emily|title=Using an Astrolabe|url= http://www.muslimheritage.com/article/using-astrolabe |website= muslimheritage.com |accessdate=6 May 2016|date=2005}}</ref>

== Determinations ==
[[File:mihrab at Jama Masjid, Fatehpur Sikri.jpg|thumb|250px|A ''[[mihrab]]'' at the 16th century [[Jama Masjid, Fatehpur Sikri|Jama Masjid]], [[Fatehpur Sikri]], indicating Qiblah|left]]
[[File:Young Muslim spplicating in Masjid al-Haram, 6 April 2015.jpg|thumb|250px|Qibla, in addition to be compulsorily maintained while establishing [[salat]], is also maintained by [[Muslims]] while [[supplication|supplicating]].]]

{{Quote|From whencesoever Thou startest forth, turn Thy face in the direction of the sacred Mosque; that is indeed the truth from the [[God|Lord]]. And [[Allah]] is not unmindful of what ye do.

So from whencesoever Thou startest forth, turn Thy face in the direction of the sacred Mosque; and wheresoever ye are, Turn your face thither: that there be no ground of dispute against you among the people, except those of them that are bent on wickedness; so fear them not, but fear Me; and that I may complete My favours on you, and ye May (consent to) be guided;|Qur'an, [[sura]] 2 ([[Al-Baqara]]), [[ayah|ayat]] 149 - 150<ref>{{Cite quran|2|149|e=150|s=ns|tn=y}}</ref>}}

{{Quote|It is not righteousness that ye turn your faces Towards east or West; but it is righteousness- to believe in Allah and the Last Day, and the [[Angel]]s, and the Book, and the [[Messengers of Islam|Messengers]]; to spend of your substance, out of love for Him, for your kin, for orphans, for the needy, for the wayfarer, for those who ask, and for the ransom of slaves; to be steadfast in prayer, and practice regular charity; to fulfil the contracts which ye have made; and to be firm and patient, in pain (or suffering) and adversity, and throughout all periods of panic. Such are the people of truth, the Allah-fearing.|Qur'an, sura 2 (Al-Baqara), ayah 177<ref>{{Cite quran|2|177|s=ns|tn=y}}</ref>}}

The two moments in each year when the sun is directly overhead the Kaaba, the sun will indicate the direction of [[Mecca]] in all countries where it is visible. This happens on May 27 or May 28 at 9:18 GMT and on July 15 or July 16 at 9:27 GMT. Likewise there are two moments in each year when the Sun is directly over the [[Antipodes|antipode]] of the Kaaba. This happens on January 12 or January 13 at 21:29 [[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]] and on November 28 at 21:09 GMT.<ref name="Abdali1997"> Abdali, S. Kamal (17 September 1997). [https://geomete.com/abdali/papers/qibla.pdf "The Correct Qibla"] (PDF). Retrieved 20 June 2019.</ref> On those dates, the direction of shadows in any sunlit place will point directly away from the Qiblah. Because the Earth is almost a sphere, this is almost the same as saying that the Qiblah from a place is the direction in which a bird would start flying in order to get to the Kaaba by the shortest possible way. The antipode of the Kaaba is in the middle of the [[Pacific Ocean]], in remote southern [[French Polynesia]], some {{convert|35|mi|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Tematangi]] [[atoll]] and {{convert|85|mi|abbr=on}} west-northwest of [[Moruroa]] atoll.

In contrast to the regular custom, there is a mosque which does not face the Qiblah. It is [[Cheraman Juma Masjid]] in the south [[India]]n state of [[Kerala]]. Unlike other mosques in the [[south Indian]] state, it faces eastwards, instead of westwards to Mecca.<ref name="BT">{{cite web
|publisher=Bahrain tribune |url=http://www.bahraintribune.com/ArticleDetail.asp?CategoryId=4&ArticleId=49332 |title=World’s second oldest mosque is in India |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060706220818/http://www.bahraintribune.com/ArticleDetail.asp?CategoryId=4&ArticleId=49332 <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->|archivedate=2006-07-06}}</ref><ref>[http://www.islamicvoice.com/june.2004/miscellany.htm#cjm Cheraman Juma Masjid A Secular Heritage]</ref><ref name="indiatravels">[http://www.indiatraveltimes.com/travelogue/mosque.html A mosque from a Hindu king]</ref>

=== Islamic mathematics ===
{{Main|Mathematics in medieval Islam}}
[[File:Al-Ashraf compass and qibla diagram.png|thumb|[[Al-Ashraf Umar II|Al-Ashraf]]'s diagram of the compass and Qibla. From MS Cairo TR 105, copied in Yemen, 1293.<ref name=Schmidl />]]

Determining the direction of the Qiblah was a central issue and a constant generator of a scientific environment during the [[Islamic Golden Age]], one that required both mathematics and observation. Muslim scientists who contributed works to determine the Qiblah direction from any point on the Earth's surface were: [[Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī|Al-Khawarizmi]], [[Habash al-Hasib al-Marwazi]], [[Al-Nayrizi]], [[Muḥammad ibn Jābir al-Ḥarrānī al-Battānī|Al-Battani]], [[Abū al-Wafā' Būzjānī]], [[Ibn Yunus]], [[Al-Sijzi]], [[Abu Nasr Mansur]], [[Ibn al-Haytham]], [[Al-Biruni]], [[Nasir al-Din al-Tusi]], [[Ibn al-Shatir]], and [[Shams al-Dīn Abū Abd Allāh al-Khalīlī|Al-Khalili]], among others.<ref name="Abdali1997"></ref><ref name="musa">{{cite journal|last=Moussa|first=Ali|title=Mathematical Methods in Abū al-Wafāʾ's Almagest and the Qibla Determinations|journal=Arabic Sciences and Philosophy|year=2011|volume=21|issue=1|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|doi=10.1017/S095742391000007X}}</ref>

The [[Yemen]]i Sultan [[al-Malik al-Ashraf]] described the use of the compass as a Qibla indicator in the 13th century.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Savage-Smith |first1=Emilie |year=1988 |title=Gleanings from an Arabist's Workshop: Current Trends in the Study of Medieval Islamic Science and Medicine |url= |journal=[[Isis (journal)|Isis]] |volume=79 |issue=2 |pages=246–266 [263] |doi=10.1086/354701}}</ref> In a treatise about [[astrolabes]] and [[sundials]], al-Ashraf includes several paragraphs on the construction of a compass bowl (ṭāsa). He then uses the compass to determine the north point, the [[meridian (astronomy)|meridian]] (khaṭṭ niṣf al-nahār), and the Qibla. This is the first mention of a compass in a medieval Islamic scientific text and its earliest known use as a Qibla indicator, although al-Ashraf did not claim to be the first to use it for this purpose.<ref name=Schmidl>{{cite journal |title=Two Early Arabic Sources On The Magnetic Compass |last=Schmidl |first=Petra G. |journal=Journal of Arabic and Islamic Studies |year=1996–97 |volume=1 |pages=81–132 |ref=harv}} http://www.uib.no/jais/v001ht/01-081-132schmidl1.htm#_ftn4</ref><ref name=BEA>{{cite encyclopedia |editor=Thomas Hockey |display-editors=et al. |last=Schmidl |first=Petra G. |title=Ashraf: al‐Malik al‐Ashraf (Mumahhid al‐Dīn) ʿUmar ibn Yūsuf ibn ʿUmar ibn ʿAlī ibn Rasūl |encyclopedia=The Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers |publisher=Springer |year=2007 |location=New York |pages=66–67 |url=http://islamsci.mcgill.ca/RASI/BEA/Ashraf_BEA.htm |isbn=9780387310220 |ref=harv}} ([http://islamsci.mcgill.ca/RASI/BEA/Ashraf_BEA.pdf PDF version])</ref>

=== North American interpretations ===
[[File:Mecca Direction Equidistant.jpg|thumb|right|The shortest direction to Kaaba in Mecca from all over the World]]

In recent years, Muslims from North America have used two rules to determine the direction of the Qiblah. According to spherical calculations, a Muslim praying from [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]], [[Alaska]] would pray almost due north if determining the Qiblah. However, when one looks at the world on most [[Mercator projection|Mercator]] map projections, Mecca appears to be southwest of Anchorage. The shortest [[rhumb line]] (line of constant bearing) from most points in North America to Mecca will point toward the southeast, but the distance to Mecca along this route on the actual surface of the earth is longer than the [[great circle]] route.

There are Muslim communities in North America who face toward the northeast, following the great circle route, and there are Muslim communities in North America who face toward the southeast according to traditional early [[Islam]]ic methods including sighting the stars, sun, etc.<ref name="Abdali1997"></ref>

Most Qiblah-calculating programs (see list below) use the great circle method and place the Qiblah northeast from most points in North America.

=== From space ===
In April 2006, the [[Malaysian National Space Agency]] sponsored a conference of scientists and religious scholars to address the issue of how the Qiblah should be determined when one is in [[orbit]]<ref>[http://www.islam-online.net/English/News/2006-04/19/article04.shtml "Malaysian Conf. Probes How Muslim Astronauts Pray"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060525005148/http://www.islam-online.net/English/News/2006-04/19/article04.shtml |date=2006-05-25 }} on ''Islam Online''</ref>. The conference concluded that the astronaut should determine the location of the Qiblah "according to [their] capability".<ref>[http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1189064958581&pagename=Zone-English-News/NWELayout "First Muslim to Fast Ramadan in Space"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117194215/http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1189064958581&pagename=Zone-English-News%2FNWELayout |date=2007-11-17 }} on ''Islam Online''</ref> There have already been [[List of Muslim astronauts|several Muslim astronauts]], among them the first being Prince [[Sultan bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]] (1985), and the latest being the first Muslim woman in space [[Anousheh Ansari]] (2006) and the Malaysian astronaut [[Sheikh Muszaphar Shukor]] (2007).

[[Ayatollah|Grand Ayatollah]] [[Ali al-Sistani]] has stated that one should face the direction of the Earth.<ref>[http://www.sistani.org/english/qa/01300/#14822 "Question & Answer - Qibla"]</ref> This is part of the Malaysian document which recommends that the qibla should be 'based on what is possible' for the astronaut, and can be prioritized this way:
1) The Ka'aba
2) The projection of Ka'aba
3) The [[Earth]]
4) Wherever.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Di Justo|first1=Patrick|title=A Muslim Astronaut's Dilemma: How to Face Mecca From Space|url=http://archive.wired.com/science/space/news/2007/09/mecca_in_orbit|accessdate=25 May 2015|publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=26 September 2007}}</ref>

[[File:QiblaPrayerDirectionSSH.jpg|right|thumb|225px|Qiblah indicated in a hotel in Egypt]]

pages.title: Tawaf
pages.text:
{{italic title}}
{{More footnotes|date=July 2017}}
[[File:Kaaba mirror edit jj.jpg|right|thumb|Crowds circling the Kaaba]]
{{Fiqh|ritual}}
'''''Tawaf''''' ({{lang-ar|طواف}}, ''Ṭawāf''; literally ''going about'') is one of the [[Islamic]] rituals of [[pilgrimage]]. During the [[Hajj]] and [[Umrah]], [[Muslims]] are to [[Circumambulation|go around]] the [[Kaaba]] (the [[Most holy place#Islam|most sacred site]] in Islam) seven times, in a [[counterclockwise]] direction; the first three circuits at a hurried pace on the outer part of the crowd, followed by four times closer to the Kaaba at a leisurely pace.<ref>World Faiths, teach yourself - Islam by Ruqaiyyah Maqsood. {{ISBN|0-340-60901-X}} page 76</ref> The circling is believed to demonstrate the unity of the believers in the worship of the One God, as they move in harmony together around the Kaaba, while supplicating to [[God in Islam|God]].

==Ritual details==

[[File:Supplicating Pilgrim at Masjid Al Haram. Mecca, Saudi Arabia.jpg|thumb|right|Large crowds of pilgrims sometimes make it difficult to perform the rituals]]
[[File:Gate of Ka-bah.JPG|right|thumb|Gate of the Kaaba]]
The circle begins from the [[Black Stone]] (''al-Ḥajar al-'Aswad'') on the corner of the Kaaba. If possible, Muslims are to kiss or touch it, but this is often not possible because of the large crowds, so it is acceptable for them to simply point or hold up their hand to the Stone on each circuit. They are also to make the [[Takbir]] prayer (''Bismillah Allahu Akbar'') each time they approach.

For men, it is recommended to do the first three circuits in a hurried pace, followed by four rounds of a more leisurely pace.

At the end of the circling, Muslims go to the [[Maqam Ibrahim|Station of Ibrahim]] to pray two [[rak'ah]]s of ''nafl'' prayer {{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}, and then drink water from the sacred [[Well of Zamzam]], before proceeding to the next ritual of the Hajj, the [[Sa'yee]].

Muslims are generally advised to "make ṭawāf" at least twice – once as part of the Hajj, and again as their final activity before leaving Mecca.<ref name=AtoZ>{{Cite book| title=Hajj to Umrah: From A to Z | last = Mohamed | first= Mamdouh N. | year = 1996 | publisher=Mamdouh Mohamed |ISBN=0-915957-54-X}}</ref>

==Types==
There are several types of ṭawāf that can be performed:
* ''Ṭawāf al-Qudūm'' ("arrival ṭawāf") is performed by those not residing in Mecca once reaching the Holy City.
* ''Ṭawāf aṭ-Ṭaḥīyah'' is performed after entering the [[Masjid al-Haram]] at any other times and is [[mustahab]].
* ''Ṭawāf al-<sup>c</sup>Umrah'' refers to the ṭawāf performed specifically for Umrah.
* ''Ṭawāf al-Wadā<sup>c</sup>'' ("farewell ṭawāf") is performed before leaving Mecca.
* ''Ṭawāf az-Zīyārah'', ''Ṭawāf al-'Ifāḍah'' or ''Ṭawāf al-Ḥajj'' is performed after casting stones, sacrificing animals (''hadi'') shaving the hair.

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}}

'''Uthman Ibn Talha''' was a [[Sahabi|companion]] of the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Read Surat Nisa 58-59|url=http://www.muftisays.com/blog/Seifeddine-M/2692_14-03-2012/surah-annisa-5859.html|location=Mecca|language=Arabic}}</ref> Before the conquest of Mecca, he was the keeper of the key to the [[Kaaba]]. He was therefore known as the "Sadin of [[Mecca]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Secret against Uthman ibn Talhah|url=http://www.shiapen.com/comprehensive/who-killed-uthman/reasons-sahabas-revolt-uthman.html|location=Mecca|date=2011}}</ref> Since Muhammad handed the key to the Kaaba over to him, descendants of Muhammad's companions have been inheriting the key and the title [[Sadin of the Kaaba]] to this day.<ref>{{cite web|title=After Mecca Conquest|url=http://www.inter-islam.org/Seerah/TheConquestofMakkahL2P1.html|location=Makkah|pages=1}}</ref>

==Conversion to Islam==
On reaching Mecca, Muhammad found that the Kaaba was locked. He said, "'Who has key?'" and was told that Uthman Ibn Talha had it.<ref name="Sadin">{{cite web|URL=http://quranalhakeem.com/story-about-keys-of-kaaba/|title=Story About Keys Of Kaaba}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|URL=http://storiesofthesahabah.tumblr.com/post/58143976361/keyholder|title=Stories of the Sahabah}}</ref> Muhammad told [[Ali]] to take the key from Uthman. Ali went to him and asked, "Can you please give me key?".<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=252958&Cat=9&dt=7/25/2010|title=History of the Ka'aba}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|URL=http://salafiaqeedah.blogspot.com/2014/02/why-is-gate-so-high.html?m=1|title=Why is the Gate So High?}}</ref> Uthman replied, "Why you are asking? Is someone at Mecca?".<ref name="Death of Current Key Keeper of Kaaba">{{cite web|URL=http://www.ciibroadcasting.com/2014/10/24/key-keeper-of-the-kabah-passes-away/|title=Key Keeper of the Kabah Passes Away}}</ref> Ali replied, "Muhammad wants this key to enter the Kaaba."<ref>{{cite web|URL=http://islamicvoice.com/January2012/ALEAFOUTOFPROPHETSBOOK/|title=Keys back with Key Bearer}}</ref> Uthman refused to hand it over. Ali snatched key from him and gave it to Muhammad.

Muhammad said that he had received a revelation inside the Kaaba, telling him to "return this key to its owner". Muhammad told Ali to return the key to Uthman Ibn Talha and to ask forgiveness for what he did. Ali went to Uthman and said to him: "O Uthman, I am here to return to you this key which you gave me and please forgive me for this my deed." Uthman laughed at him and said, "First you came here to snatch the key from me and now you come to me to return the key" Ali said, "I took the key from you, but Muhammad received a revelation to return it to you. Ali told the Ayah and Uthman said, "Ash Hadu Allahilaha Ilalla Wahdahu La Sharika Lahu Wa Ash Hadu Ana Muhammadan Abduh Wa Rasoolu''," and converted to Islam.<ref name=Sadin/>

Waqidi records that Uthman converted to Islam in June 629 at the same time as [[Khalid ibn al-Walid]] and lived in [[Medina]] until the Muslim army set out for the conquest.<ref name=Waqidi>Muhammad ibn Umar al-Waqidi. ''Kitab al-Maghazi''. Translated by Faizer, R., Ismail, A., & Tayyob, A. K. (2011). ''The Life of Muhammad'', p. 410. London & New York: Routledge.</ref>

==Conquest of Mecca==
Upon the [[Conquest of Mecca]] in January 630, Muhammad handed the key to the Shayba family, announcing, "Take it, O Children of Talha, eternally up to the Day of Resurrection, and it will not be taken from you unless by an unjust, oppressive tyrant."<ref name="Death of Current Key Keeper of Kaaba"/>

Thereafter Uthman ibn Talha was acknowledged as one of Muhammad's best companions.<ref name=Sadin/>

pages.title: Year of the Elephant
pages.text:
The '''ʿām al-fīl ''' ({{lang-ar|عام الفيل}}, '''Year of the [[Elephant]]''') is the name in [[Islam]]ic history for the year approximately equating to 570 [[Christian Era|CE]]. According to some Islamic resources, it was in this year that [[Muhammad]] ({{lang-ar|مُـحَـمَّـد}}, consonant letters: m-ħ-m-d) was born.Hajjah Adil, Amina, "''Prophet Muhammad''", ISCA, Jun 1, 2002, {{ISBN|1-930409-11-7}} The name is derived from an event said to have occurred at [[Mecca]]: [[Abraha]], the [[Habasha|Abyssinian]], [[Christians|Christian]] ruler of [[Yemen]], which was subject to the [[Kingdom of Aksum]] of [[Ethiopia]],[http://www.dacb.org/stories/ethiopia/_abraha.html "Abraha."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113213718/http://www.dacb.org/stories/ethiopia/_abraha.html |date=2016-01-13 }} ''Dictionary of African Christian Biographies''. 2007. (last accessed 11 April 2007)[http://www.yemenweb.com/info/_disc/0000002c.htm Walter W. Müller, "Outline of the History of Ancient Southern Arabia," in Werner Daum (ed.), ''Yemen: 3000 Years of Art and Civilisation in Arabia Felix''. 1987.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010075912/http://www.yemenweb.com/info/_disc/0000002c.htm |date=2014-10-10 }} marched upon the [[Ka‘bah]] in [[Mecca]] with a large army, which included one or more [[war elephant]]s, intending to demolish it. However, the lead elephant, known as 'Mahmud' ({{lang-ar|مَـحْـمُـوْد}}, consonant letters: m-ħ-m-w-d),{{cite web | title = Tafsir of Surah al Fil - The Elephant (Surah 105) | url = http://islaam.net/main/display.php?id=1480&category=176 | work = Translated by Abū Rumaysah | publisher = Islamic Network | accessdate = 15 March 2013 | author = ʿAbdu r-Rahmān ibn Nāsir as-Saʿdī | authorlink = Abd ar-Rahman ibn Nasir as-Sa'di | quote = This elephant was called Mahmud and it was sent to Abrahah from [[Negus|Najashi]], the king of Abyssinia, particularly for this expedition. | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101220090653/http://islaam.net/main/display.php?id=1480&category=176 | archivedate = 20 December 2010 | df = }} is said to have stopped at the boundary around Mecca, and refused to enter. It has been theorized that an [[epidemic]], perhaps caused by [[smallpox]], could have caused such a failed invasion of Mecca.{{cite journal |author=[[John S. Marr|Marr JS]], Hubbard E, Cathey, JT |date=2015 |title=The Year of the Elephant |url=https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/The_Year_of_the_Elephant |journal=Wikiversity Journal of Medicine |publisher= |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages= |doi=10.15347/wjm/2015.003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526193449/https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/The_Year_of_the_Elephant |archivedate=2015-05-26 |df= }}
In turn citing: {{cite book |author= Willan R. |title= Miscellaneous works: comprising An inquiry into the antiquity of the small-pox, measles, and scarlet fever, now first published; Reports on the diseases in London, a new ed.; and detached papers on medical subjects, collected from various periodical publi |publisher= Cadell |date= 1821 |pages= 488. |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=TXEFAAAAQAAJ&pgis=1 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150904004402/https://books.google.com/books?id=TXEFAAAAQAAJ&pgis=1 |archivedate= 2015-09-04 |df= }} The year came to be known as the Year of the Elephant, beginning a trend for reckoning the years in the [[Arabian Peninsula]]. This reckoning was used until it was replaced with the [[Islamic calendar]] during the times of ‘[[Umar]]. Archaeological discoveries in [[Southern Arabia]] suggest that Year of the Elephant may have been 569 or 568, as the [[Sasanian Empire]] overthrew the [[Kingdom of Aksum|Aksumite]]-affiliated rulers in Yemen around 570. The year is also recorded as that of the birth of ‘[[Ammar ibn Yasir]].{{Cite book|title=New Researchers on the Quran: Why and how two versions of Islam entered the history of mankind|last=Azmayesh|first=Seyed Mostafa|publisher=Mehraby Publishing House|year=2015|isbn=9780955811760|location=United Kingdom|pages=262}} == Events == According to early Islamic historians such as [[Ibn Ishaq]], in honor of his ally, [[Negus]] Abraha built a great [[Church (building)|church]] at [[Sana'a]] known as ''[[Al-Qalis Church, Sana'a|al-Qullays]]'', a [[loanword]] borrowed from {{lang-el|εκκλησία}} "church". Al-Qullays gained widespread fame, even gaining the notice of the [[Byzantine Empire]]. The [[paganism|pagan]] [[Arab people]] of the time had their own center of religious worship and [[Hajj|pilgrimage]] in Mecca, the Kaaba. Abraha attempted to divert their pilgrimage to al-Qullays and appointed a man named Muhammad ibn Khuza'i {{cn|date=November 2018}} to Mecca and [[Tihamah]] as a king with a message that al-Qullays was both much better than other houses of worship and purer, having not been defiled by the housing of idols. Ibn Ishaq's [[Prophetic biography]] states:{{cquote|With Abraha there were some Arabs who had come to seek his bounty, among them Muhammad ibn Khuza`i ibn Khuzaba al-Dhakwani, al-Sulami, with a number of his tribesmen including a brother of his called Qays. While they were with him a feast of Abraha occurred and he sent to invite them to the feast. Now he used to eat an animal's testicles, so when the invitation was brought they said, "By God, if we eat this the Arabs will hold it against us as long as we live." Thereupon Muhammad ibn Khuza'i got up and went to Abraha and said, "O King, this is a festival of ours in which we eat only the loins and shoulders." Abraha replied that he would send them what they liked because his sole purpose in inviting them was to show that he honored them. Then he crowned Muhammad ibn Khuza'i, and made him [[emir]] of [[Adnanites|Mudhar]], and ordered him to go among the people to invite them to pilgrimage at his cathedral which he had built. When Muhammad ibn Khuza'i got as far as the land of [[Banu Kinanah|Kinana]], the people of the lowland, knowing what he had come for, sent a man of [[Banu Hudhayl|Hudhayl]] called ʿUrwa bin Hayyad al-Milasi, who shot him with an arrow, killing him. His brother Qays who was with him fled to Abraha and told him the news, which increased his rage and fury and he swore to raid the Kinana tribe and destroy the temple.}}{{cn|date=November 2018}} Ibn Ishaq further states that one of the men of the [[Quraysh tribe]] was angered by this, and going to Sana'a, slipped into the church at night and defiled it; it is widely assumed that he did so by [[defecation|defecating]] in it. Abraha, incensed, launched an expedition of forty thousand men against the Ka‘bah at Mecca, led by a white elephant named ''Mahmud''{{cite book|last=Kistler|first=John M. ; foreword by Richard Lair|title=War elephants|year=2007|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln|isbn=0803260040|page=177|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-5RHK4Ol15QC&lpg=PA177&pg=PA177#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=The Year of The Elephant|quote=The lead elephant, named [[White elephant|'''Mahmud''']], stopped and knelt down, refusing to go further.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109135635/https://books.google.com/books?id=-5RHK4Ol15QC&lpg=PA177&pg=PA177#v=onepage&q&f=false|archivedate=2016-01-09|df=}} (and possibly with other elephants - some accounts state there were several elephants, or even as many as eightWilliam Montgomery Watt (1961). [https://archive.org/details/in.gov.ignca.29762 ''Muhammad: Prophet and Statesman''], Oxford: Oxford University Press, p. 7.) in order to destroy the Ka‘bah. Several Arab tribes attempted to fight him on the way, but were defeated. When news of the advance of Abraha's army came, the Arab tribes of the Quraysh, Banu Kinanah, [[Banu Khuza'a]] and Banu Hudhayl united in defense of the Ka‘bah. A man from the [[Himyarite Kingdom]] was sent by Abraha to advise him that Abraha only wished to demolish the Kaaba and if they resisted, they would be crushed. [[Abd_al-Muttalib|‘Abdul Muttalib]] told the Meccans to seek refuge in the hills while he with some leading members of the Quraysh remained within the precincts of the Ka‘bah. Abraha sent a dispatch inviting Abdul-Muttalib to meet with Abraha and discuss matters. When Abdul-Muttalib left the meeting he was heard saying, "The Owner of this House is its Defender, and I am sure He will save it from the attack of the adversaries and will not dishonor the servants of His House." The reference to the story in [[Qur’an]] is rather short. According to [[Sura]]h [[al-Fil]], the next day [as Abraha prepared to enter the city], a dark cloud of [[Restless flycatcher|small birds]] named '[[Ababil (mythology)|Ababil]]' ({{lang-ar|أَبـابـيـل}}) appeared. The birds carried [[Lava|small rocks]] in their beaks, and bombarded the Ethiopian forces and smashed them like "eaten straw". ==Shia== According to [[Hadith]], in al-Kafi Volume one, Imam [[Ali]] was born in the 30th year of the Elephant{{cite web |title=The birth of El Imam Ali related to the year of the elephant |url=http://balaghah.net/old/nahj-htm/eng/id/article/46.htm |website=balaghah.net |accessdate=24 July 2018}} and died in AH 40.{{cite book|last1=Al-Islam|first1=Thiqatu|title=Al-Kafi|date=2015|publisher=Islamic Seminary Inc.|location=New York|isbn=978-0-9914308-6-4|page=457|edition=Second|url=http://www.theislamicseminary.org/wp/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027221543/http://www.theislamicseminary.org/wp/|archivedate=2017-10-27|df=}} == Other sources == This event is referred to in the Qur’an, in [[Sura]]h 105, ''[[Al-Fil]]'' ({{lang-ar|الـفِـيـل}}, "The Elephant"), and is discussed in its related [[tafsir]]. Some scholars have placed the Year of the Elephant one or two decades earlier than 570 CE,{{cite book|page=154|title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Modern Islamic World: Libe-Sare|last1=Esposito|first1=John L.|authorlink=John L. Esposito|year=1995|isbn=978-0195096149|publisher=Oxford University Press}} with a tradition attributed to [[Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri]] in the works of [[‘Abd al-Razzaq al-San‘ani]] placing it before the birth of Muhammad's father.{{cite book|page=3-5|title=The Expeditions: An Early Biography of Muhammad|publisher=NYU Press|last1=ibn Rashid|first1=Mamar|translator=Sean W. Anthony|isbn=978-0814769638}} ==See also== * [[War elephant]] * [[Cultural depictions of elephants]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.islamic-awareness.org/Quran/Sources/BBdefense.html Page at Islamic-Awareness.org discussing the event] {{DEFAULTSORT:Year Of The Elephant}} [[Category:Life of Muhammad]] [[Category:History of Mecca]] [[Category:Kaaba]] [[Category:Shia days of remembrance]] [[Category:Pre-Islamic Arabia]] [[Category:Islamic terminology]] [[Category:Elephants in culture]]

'''Abd al-'Aziz ibn Muhammad al-Qahiri al-Wafa'i''' known as '''Ibn al-Aqba'i''' (1408–1471) was an [[Egyptians |Egyptian]] astronomer and mathematician in the 15th century. He was born in 811 H.E. (1408 AD) and died in 876 H.E (1471 AD). Some sources say that he died in 874 or 879 H.E. He was a student of [[Ibn al-Majdi]] and [[Nur al-din al-Naqqash]]. He became a time keeper at the Mu'ayyad Mosque in [[Cairo]]. He also became the chief of the time keepers of the Azhar mosque and the Maridani Mosque. He was interested in the calculation of the local times of cities based on their latitude and longitude. He invented an astronomical device called Da'irah al-Mu'addal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://islamport.com/w/trj/Web/288/848.htm |title=الموسوعة الشاملة - الضوء اللامع |publisher=Islamport.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eternalegypt.org/EternalEgyptWebsiteWeb/HomeServlet?ee_website_action_key=action.display.element&story_id=&module_id=&language_id=3&element_id=1678&ee_messages=0001.flashrequired.text |title=مصر الخالدة  - عبدالعزيز الوفائي |publisher=Eternalegypt.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-02}}</ref>

He wrote about 40 books and 20 treatises on [[mathematics]] and [[astronomy]], none of them published. Among his works is the manuscript Risalah al-'Amal bi al-Rub' al-Mujayyab

'''Abū ʿAbd Allāh Muḥammad ibn Jābir ibn Sinān al-Raqqī al-Ḥarrānī aṣ-Ṣābiʾ al-Battānī''' ({{lang-ar|محمد بن جابر بن سنان البتاني}}) ([[Latinization (literature)|Latinized]] as '''Albategnius''', '''Albategni''' or '''Albatenius''') (c. 858 – 929) was an [[Arabs|Arab]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=C.A.|first1=Nallino|title=al-BATTĀNĪ|publisher=Brill|language=en|doi=10.1163/1573-3912_islam_sim_1289}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Battānī {{!}} Arab astronomer and mathematician|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/al-Battani|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Battani - Oxford Reference|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095359912|language=en}}</ref> [[Islamic astronomy|astronomer]], [[Islamic astrology|astrologer]], and [[Islamic mathematics|mathematician]]. He introduced a number of trigonometric relations, and his ''Kitāb az-Zīj'' was frequently quoted by many medieval astronomers, including [[Copernicus]].<ref name="Hartner 2008">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Hartner | first = Willy | title =Al-Battānī, Abū ʿAbd Allāh Muḥammad Ibn Jābir Ibn Sinān al-Raqqī al-Ḥarrānī al–Ṣābi | encyclopedia = [[Dictionary of Scientific Biography]] | publisher = [[Charles Scribner's Sons]] | location = New York | date=1970–80 | isbn = 978-0-684-10114-9 | url = http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-2830900300.html}}</ref>

Al-Battani is sometimes referred to as the "[[Ptolemy]] of the [[Arabs]]",<ref>Barlow, Peter; Kater, Henry; Herschel, Sir John Frederick William (1856). The Encyclopaedia of Astronomy: Comprising Plane Astronomy. R. Griffin. p. 494.</ref> and is widely considered the greatest and best known [[Islamic astronomy|astronomer]] of the medieval Islamic world.<ref>Schlager, Neil; Lauer, Josh (2001). Science and Its Times: 700-1449. Gale Group. p. 291.</ref><ref>Griffin, Rosarii (2006). Education in the Muslim World: different perspectives. Symposium Books Ltd. p. 31.
</ref><ref>Angelo, Joseph A. (2014). Encyclopedia of Space and Astronomy. Infobase Publishing. p. 78.</ref><ref>Ben-Menaḥem, Ari (2009). Historical Encyclopedia of Natural and Mathematical Sciences. Springer Science & Business Media. p. 541.</ref>

==Life==
Little is known about al-Battānī's life beside that he was born in [[Harran]] near [[Urfa]], in Upper [[Mesopotamia]], which is now in [[Turkey]], and his father was a famous maker of scientific instruments.<ref name="Hartner 2008"/> His epithet ''aṣ-Ṣabi’'' suggests that among his ancestry  were members of the [[Sabians|Sabian]] sect; however, his full name indicates that he was [[Muslim]].<ref name=MacTutor>{{MacTutor Biography|id=Al-Battani}}</ref> Some western historians state that he is of noble origin, like an [[Arab]] prince,<ref name="B1911">{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Albategnius |volume=1 |page=491}}</ref> but traditional Arabic biographers make no mention of this.<ref name="Hartner 2008"/> He lived and worked in [[Raqqa]], a city in north central [[Syria]].

==Astronomy==
One of al-Battānī's best-known achievements in astronomy was the determination of the solar year as being 365 days, 5 hours, 46 minutes and 24 seconds which is only 2 minutes and 22 seconds off.<ref name=MacTutor />

He was able to correct some of Ptolemy's results and compiled new tables of the [[Sun]] and [[Moon]], long accepted as authoritative.<ref name="B1911" /> Some of his measurements were even more accurate than ones taken by [[Copernicus]] many centuries later. Researchers have ascribed this phenomenon to al-Battānī's location lying closer to the equator so that the [[ecliptic]] and the Sun were higher in the sky and therefore less susceptible to [[atmospheric refraction]].<ref name=MacTutor />

Al-Battānī discovered that the direction of the Sun's [[apogee]], as recorded by Ptolemy, was changing.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = [[Courier Dover Publications]]| isbn = 978-0-486-29887-0| last = Singer| first = Charles Joseph| title = A short history of science to the nineteenth century| date = 1997| page=135}}</ref> (In modern heliocentric terms this is due to the changing direction of the [[eccentricity vector]] of the Earth's orbit). He also introduced, probably independently of the 5th century [[India]]n astronomer [[Aryabhata]], the use of [[sine]]s in calculation, and partially that of [[tangent (trigonometric function)|tangent]]s.<ref name="B1911" /> He also calculated the values for the [[precession]] of the equinoxes (54.5" per year, or 1° in 66 years) and the [[obliquity| obliquity of the ecliptic]] (23° 35').<ref name=MacTutor /> He used a uniform rate for precession in his tables, choosing not to adopt the theory of [[trepidation]] attributed to his colleague [[Thabit ibn Qurra]].

Al-Battānī's work is considered instrumental in the development of science and astronomy.<ref name=MacTutor /> [[Nicolaus Copernicus|Copernicus]] quoted him in the book that initiated the [[Copernican Revolution]], the ''[[De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium]]'', where his name is mentioned no fewer than 23 times,<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]]| isbn = 9780521576000| last = Hoskin| first = Michael| title = The Cambridge Concise History of Astronomy| date = 1999-03-18|page=58}}</ref> and also mentioned him in the ''[[Commentariolus]]''.<ref name=freely>{{Cite book| publisher = [[I.B.Tauris]]| isbn = 9781784531386| last = Freely| first = John| title = Light from the East: How the Science of Medieval Islam Helped to Shape the Western World| date = 2015-03-30| page=179}}</ref> Al-Battānī was frequently quoted by [[Tycho Brahe]] and [[Riccioli]], among others. [[Kepler]] and [[Galileo]] showed interest in some of his observations,<ref name="Hartner 2008"/> and his data continues to be used in geophysics.<ref>Dalmau, W. (1997) [http://hbar.phys.msu.ru/gorm/atext/dalmau.htm CRITICAL REMARKS ON THE USE OF MEDIEVAL ECLIPSE RECORDS FOR THE DETERMINATION OF LONG-TERM CHANGES IN THE EARTH'S ROTATION]', Surveys in Geophysics 18: 213-223.</ref>

The major [[Lunar craters|lunar crater]] [[Albategnius (crater)|Albategnius]] is named in his honor.<ref>Ewen A. Whitaker, ''Mapping and Naming the Moon'' (Cambridge University Press, 1999), p.61.</ref>

==Mathematics==

In [[Islamic mathematics|mathematics]], al-Battānī produced a number of [[Trigonometry|trigonometrical]] relationships:

::<math>\tan a = \frac{\sin a}{\cos a}</math>

::<math>\sec a = \sqrt{1 + \tan^2 a }</math>

He also solved the equation sin ''x'' = ''a'' cos ''x'' discovering the formula:

::<math>\sin x = \frac{a}{\sqrt{1 + a^2}}</math>

He gives other trigonometric formulae for right-angled triangles such as:<ref name="MacTutor"/>

::<math>b \sin (A) = a \sin (90^\circ - A)</math>

Al-Battānī used [[Habash al-Hasib al-Marwazi|al-Marwazi]]'s idea of [[Trigonometric function|tangents]] ("shadows") to develop equations for calculating tangents and cotangents, compiling tables of them. He also discovered the reciprocal functions of secant and cosecant, and produced the first table of cosecants, which he referred to as a "table of shadows" (in reference to the shadow of a [[gnomon]]), for each degree from 1° to 90°.<ref name=trigonometry>{{cite web|title=trigonometry|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/605281/trigonometry|publisher=''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]''|accessdate=2008-07-21}}</ref>

== Works ==

Al-Battānī's major work is ''Kitāb az-Zīj'' ("Book of [[zij|Astronomical Tables]]"). It was largely based on Ptolemy's theory, and other Greco-Syriac sources, while showing little Indian or Persian influence.<ref name="Hartner 2008"/><ref>E. S. Kennedy, ''A Survey of Islamic Astronomical Tables,'' (Transactions of the American Philosophical Society, New Series, 46, 2), Philadelphia, 1956, pp. 10–11, 32–34.</ref> In his [[zij]], he provided descriptions of a [[Quadrant (instrument)|quadrant]] instrument.<ref name="musa">{{cite journal|last=Moussa|first=Ali|title=Mathematical Methods in Abū al-Wafāʾ's Almagest and the Qibla Determinations|journal=Arabic Sciences and Philosophy|date=2011|volume=21|issue=1|pages=1–56|doi=10.1017/S095742391000007X}}</ref>

This book went through many translations to Latin and Spanish, including a Latin translation as ''De Motu Stellarum'' by [[Plato Tiburtinus|Plato of Tivoli]] in 1116, which was later reprinted with annotations by [[Regiomontanus]].<ref name="B1911" /> A reprint appeared at [[Bologna]] in 1645. The original MS. is preserved at the Vatican; and the Escorial library possesses in MS. a treatise of some value by him on astronomical chronology.<ref name="B1911" />

== In popular culture ==
A ship in ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'' is named after Al-Battānī, known as the USS Al-Batani, which Janeway originally served on.
